channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Five seriously injured in Breighton airfield helicopter crash
item.description: Five people have been seriously injured in a helicopter crash at an airfield in Breighton, East Yorkshire, police say.

item.title: Cyclist Boardman's mum dies after collision
item.description: Olympic cyclist Chris Boardman's mother Carol dies after a collision with a pick up truck, as she was cycling in north Wales.

item.title: Boris Johnson plane has to make emergency landing
item.description: A small military aircraft carrying newly-appointed Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson is forced to make an emergency landing on its way to Brussels, following a "technical issue".

item.title: Turkey coup arrests hit 6,000 as Erdogan roots out 'virus'
item.description: Arrests in Turkey after Friday's failed coup rise to around 6,000, as President Erdogan vows to cleanse state bodies of the "virus" that caused it.

item.title: EU migrants may face 'right to stay' curbs - David Davis
item.description: Migrants who come to the UK before it exits the EU may not be given the right to stay, the new Brexit secretary says.

item.title: Labour's Owen Smith vows to tackle inequality
item.description: Owen Smith vows to rewrite part of Labour's constitution to put tackling inequality at its heart, as he launches his leadership bid.

item.title: Sturgeon: Second independence referendum could be next year
item.description: Nicola Sturgeon said she would consider a second referendum on Scottish independence in the first half of next year, if necessary.

item.title: Nice attack: Driver 'researched route' earlier in week
item.description: The Tunisian man who carried out the lorry attack in the French city of Nice researched his route in the days beforehand, French media reports say.

item.title: HS2 rail project backed by new transport secretary
item.description: The new transport secretary, Chris Grayling, says he has no plans to scrap the high-speed HS2 rail project.

item.title: Brexit 'will be horrible for UK economy' - fund manager
item.description: The vote to leave the European Union will have a "horrible" impact on the UK economy, which could "judder to a halt", a leading fund manager warns.

item.title: Davis Cup: Kyle Edmund win seals GB victory over Serbia
item.description: Kyle Edmund beats Serbia's Dusan Lajovic to give Great Britain an unassailable 3-1 lead to take them into the Davis Cup semi-finals.

item.title: Baton Rouge shooting: Reporter describes scene
item.description: An ABC reporter describes the scene after three police officers were shot dead in the US city of Baton Rouge.

item.title: Turkey coup: Soldier attacked by 'baying' crowd
item.description: Footage shows the moment a soldier surrenders and is pulled from his tank by a police officer, after being attacked by a crowd.

item.title: Attack in Nice: Muslims describe tensions after lorry attack
item.description: French Muslims in Nice speak about the tensions that have arisen since the beachfront lorry attack on city.

item.title: Labour leadership: Angela Eagle and Owen Smith clash
item.description: Labour leadership challengers Angela Eagle and Owen Smith set out why each of them think they would be the best leader of their party.

item.title: Wimbledon: Tennis tournament's secret cyber security
item.description: BBC News gained exclusive access to the secrets of the tech experts protecting Wimbledon from cyber attacks.

item.title: Steven Spielberg and Mark Rylance's Big Friendly bromance
item.description: Steven Spielberg and Mark Rylance talk about working together again in the film version of Roald Dahl's The BFG.

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn learns to play Pokemon Go
item.description: BBC reporter Adam Fleming shows the Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn how to play Pokemon Go.

item.title: Bringing the Battle of Hastings to life at Battle Abbey
item.description: Dr Michael Carter explains how English Heritage will mark the 950th anniversary of the Battle of Hastings with a new exhibition at Battle Abbey.

item.title: BBC News Channel
item.description: Britain's most-watched news channel, delivering breaking news and analysis all day, every day.

item.title: US election: What's the point of a party convention?
item.description: Every four years, US political parties hold conventions to make official whom they've selected to become their nominee for president. But what actually happens there?

item.title: Jacob Zuma painting: Are South Africans 'too free'?
item.description: Is South Africa's constitution too liberal for its people, asks the BBC's Milton Nkosi.

item.title: Hugh Schofield: Attack in Nice brings danger close to home
item.description: The attacker who killed 84 people in Nice proves that no longer do jihadists require careful planning and cash. The danger today is from minor offenders much closer to home.

item.title: New day, new Chancellor, new economic policy?
item.description: In all the fuss over the EU referendum and new prime minister, it has been easy to forget that the UK's economic policy has changed radically.

item.title: Iain Watson: Can Jeremy Corbyn win again?
item.description: As the Labour party heads into a leadership battle, the make-up of the party's existing and newest membership comes under intense scrutiny.

item.title: Sonia Sodha: Is the left's big new idea the 'right to be lazy'?
item.description: Why are so many on the left now arguing that the state should pay everyone a universal basic income?

item.title: The importance of the Trident decision
item.description: MPs prepare to debate the future of Britain's nuclear deterrent but is there still a need for a British bomb?

item.title: Trump's vice-presidential pick: What you need to know
item.description: Donald Trump has picked Indiana governor Mike Pence as his running mate. So who is he, and what can he do for Trump's chances of victory?

item.title: Why don't Syrian refugees stay in Turkey?
item.description: More than a million migrants crossed the Mediterranean last year to reach Europe - many of them Syrians. We answer readers' questions about why they were prepared to risk their lives.

item.title: How food, clothing and homeware bills are likely to rise
item.description: Food, clothing and electrical items are likely to rise in price as a result of Brexit - but bills may not go up until next year

item.title: Why South Sudan is on the verge of civil war
item.description: Why is South Sudan on the verge of another civil war?

item.title: Line: A guide to Japan's messenger giant
item.description: You might not have heard of Line, but the Japanese equivalent of Whatsapp is set to go public. Here's what you need to know about the company.

item.title: Iran nuclear talks: The tempers and tweets which led to a deal
item.description: One year since the historic signing of the Iranian nuclear deal, key negotiators tell BBC Persian about what went on behind the scenes.

item.title: Do Corbyn and Blair have something in common?
item.description: Prof Archie Brown says Labour's leadership crisis has its roots in the party's recent past.

item.title: Entertainment week in Pictures: 9 - 15 July
item.description: A look at some of the events in the world of entertainment and arts over the past week.

item.title: Week in pictures: 9-15 July 2016
item.description: A selection of the best news photographs from around the world, taken over the past week.

item.title: World Architecture Festival
item.description: A house with a panoramic view of the ocean in Australia and a happiness centre in Bhutan are among the projects shortlisted for the World Architecture Festival awards

item.title: The Open highlights
item.description: Extended highlights of the final round of the 145th Open Championship from Royal Troon, presented by Hazel Irvine.

item.title: The Open 2016: Henrik Stenson beats Phil Mickelson to win at Royal Troon
item.description: Henrik Stenson becomes the first Swede to win The Open after an enthralling tussle with Phil Mickelson at Royal Troon.

item.title: England v Pakistan: Tourists win Lord's thriller
item.description: England are denied a record Lord's victory by Pakistan, following an inspired bowling display from the tourists.

item.title: Tour de France: Chris Froome maintains lead as Jarlinson Pantano wins stage 15
item.description: Jarlinson Pantano wins stage 15 of the Tour de France as Great Britain's Chris Froome stays in the yellow jersey.

item.title: Sharing secrets
item.description: The lessons on intelligence-sharing learned after 7/7 may be one reason that the UK has been more fortunate than France in avoiding terror attacks, says the BBC's Peter Taylor.

item.title: The copwatchers
item.description: Two years on from the death of Eric Garner, ordinary people in New York are capturing the NYPD on camera.

item.title: Chart smash
item.description: Fewer records than ever before are making the UK top 40 as fans keep streaming the same songs over and over again. But what does that mean for music and new artists in particular?

item.title: For or against
item.description: Research suggests that a person's views on the death penalty and public whipping are a far better indicator of their views on Brexit than their social class and income.

item.title: Hendrix's hit-maker
item.description: His discovery of a young Jimi Hendrix in a New York coffee house would change the face of music. Twenty years on from Chas Chandler's death, those who knew him look back at his life.

item.title: Your pictures
item.description: Each week, we publish a gallery of readers' pictures on a set theme. This week, we asked for your pictures on the theme of "posters".

item.title: War children
item.description: The story of how nearly 4,000 child evacuees arrived after the UK government yielded to public opinion.

item.title: 10 things
item.description: Ducklings are capable of abstract thought, plus more news nuggets.

item.title: Turkey coup attempt: UK Foreign Office relaxes travel advice
item.description: The Foreign Office relaxes travel advice for Britons visiting Turkey following the failed coup, saying the situation "appears to be calming".

item.title: Why did Turkish coup plot fail?
item.description: The Turkish coup attempt was short-lived with several key factors causing it to fail, says the BBC's Paul Kirby.

item.title: Who was behind attempted coup?
item.description: As Turkey reels from a failed coup by members of the military, Turkish journalist Ezgi Basaran looks at the possible reasons and actors behind the attempt.

item.title: Clash on Bosphorus Bridge
item.description: Images of the confrontation on Istanbul's Bosphorus Bridge between soldiers trying to overthrow the government, and a group of supporters of Turkish President Recep Erdogan.

item.title: How Turkish media were raided during coup attempt
item.description: How two broadcasters and a newspaper in Turkey were taken over by a faction of the armed forces trying to seize control of the country.

item.title: Aftermath in pictures
item.description: Images from the morning after a failed coup attempt in Turkey, which the government says has left more than 160 people dead and lead to the arrest of nearly 3,000 soldiers.
